journal-title-group.journal-title: PM & R : the journal of injury, function, and rehabilitation

title-group.article-title: Diagnostic Profiles Associated with Long-Term Opioid Therapy in Active Duty Servicemembers

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Medical and Clinical Psychology, Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, Bethesda, MD
3The Henry M. Jackson Foundation for the Advancement of Military Medicine, Inc., Bethesda, MD
4Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Brigham and Women’s Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA
5Boston University School of Public Health, Department of Health Law, Policy and Management, Boston, MA
6Veterans Health Administration, Rocky Mountain Mental Illness Research Education and Clinical Center, Aurora, CO.
7Center for Health Services Research, Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, Bethesda, Maryland

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence should be addressed to: Steven Dufour, c/o Joshua Gray, 4301 Jones Bridge Road, B1032B, Bethesda, MD 20814, Steven.dufour@usuhs.edu, Phone: 301-295-0374

sec.title: Introduction:
sec.p: Over-prescription of opioids has diminished in recent years; however, certain populations remain at high risk. There is a dearth of research evaluating prescription rates using specific multimorbidity patterns.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: Identify distinct clinical profiles associated with opioid prescription and evaluate their relative odds of receiving long-term opioid therapy.

sec.title: Design:
sec.p: Retrospective analysis of the complete military electronic health record. We assessed demographics and 26 physiological, psychological, and pain conditions present during initial opioid prescription. Latent class analysis (LCA) identified unique clinical profiles using diagnostic data. Logistic regression measured these classes’ odds of receiving long-term opioid therapy.

sec.title: Setting:
sec.p: All electronic health data under the TRICARE network.

sec.title: Participants:
sec.p: All servicemembers on active duty during fiscal years 2016–2019 who filled at least one opioid prescription.

sec.title: Main Outcome Measures:
sec.p: Number and qualitative characteristics of LCA classes; odds ratios (OR) from logistic regression. We hypothesized LCA classes characterized by high-risk contraindications would have significantly higher odds of long-term opioid therapy.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: N = 714,446 active duty servicemembers were prescribed an opioid during the study window, with 12,940 (1.8%) receiving long-term opioid therapy. LCA identified 5 classes: Relatively Healthy (82%); Musculoskeletal Acute Pain and Substance Use Disorders (6%); High Pain, Low Mental Health Burden (9%); Low Pain, High Mental Health Burden (2%), and Multidomain Multimorbid (1%). Logistic regression found that, compared to the Relatively Healthy reference, the Multidomain Multimorbid class, characterized by multiple opioid contraindications, had the highest odds of receiving long-term opioid therapy (OR = 9.24; p < 0.0001; 95% CI: 8.56, 9.98).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Analyses demonstrated that classes with greater multimorbidity at the time of prescription, particularly co-occurring psychiatric and pain disorders, had higher likelihood of long-term opioid therapy. Overall, this study helps identify patients most at risk for long-term opioid therapy and has implications for healthcare policy and patient care.
